questions.text: The blood picture of a patient with anemia shows normocytic and normochromic red cells. The cause is hypoproliferative anemias if the reticulocyte index is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

< 2 Hypo-proliferative anemia: Anemia associated with normocytic and normochromic red cells and Low reticulocyte response (reticulocyte index < 2–2.5 ) Types and causes: Early iron deficiency – Most common cause (MC ) Acute and chronic inflammation – 2nd MC Malignancies Renal disease Hypometabolic state (protein malnutrition, endocrine deficiencies) Marrow damage

Extraedge:

The anemia of inflammation is related in part to abnormal iron metabolism. All other hypo-proliferative anemias (Except iron deficiency) have suboptima l erythropoietin response to the anemia. Option A , B and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Anemia is a condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Having anemia, also referred to as low hemoglobin, can make you feel tired and weak. There are many forms of anemia, each with its own cause. Which is the most common anemia among the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypoproliferative anemias The most common anemias are the hypoproliferative anemias And amongst them , iron deficiency anemia is the most common The 2 nd most common being anemia of inflammation.

Extraedge:

The two major forms of treatment are transfusions and EPO (Erythropoietin) Option: A, C: In the clinic, iron deficiency anemia is the most common of these followed by the anemia of inflammation. Option: D: Less common.

questions.text: Anemia associated with which of the following is/are characterized by a suboptimal erythropoietin response to the anemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Erythropoietin (EPO) is a glycoprotein hormone , naturally produced by the peritubular cells of the kidney, that stimulates red blood cell production Endogenous EPO production is inadequate for the degree of anemia in: Anemia of chronic inflammation (ACI) Renal disease Hypometabolism Hence characterized by suboptimal erythropoietin response to the anemia

Extraedge:

In ACI, the erythroid marrow responds inadequately to EPO stimulation, due in part to defective iron reutilization . In iron deficiency or marrow damage endogenous EPO is elevated Exploring the provenance of erythropoietin resistance may be facilitated by the consideration of the pathogenetic triad of iron-restricted erythropoiesis, inflammation, and bone marrow suppression. Option: A, B, C: All are characterized by a suboptimal erythropoietin response to the anemia.

questions.text: A newborn baby was recently diagnosed with g6pd deficient anaemia. Lumbar pain was present. There was also the presence of dark urine. All of the following are false except.

options.label: A
options.text: Increase risk of developing neonatal jaundice

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase risk of developing neonatal jaundice
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase risk of developing neonatal jaundice The clinical scenario is of neonatal jaundice due to G6PD deficiency. G6PD is a housekeeping enzyme critical in the redox metabolism of all aerobic cells It is the only source of NADPH , which via glutathione defends RBC’s against oxidative stress. The G6PD gene is X –linked . ( Option B is false) Most people with G6PD deficiency remain clinically asymptomatic . All of them have an increased risk of developing neonatal jaundice (NNJ).( Option A is true) It confers a relative resistance against Falciparum ( Option C is false) Rarely there can be aplastic anemia secondary to bone marrow damage. (Option D is false)

Highyeild:

Single missense point mutation NNJ can be very severe in some G6PD-deficient babies, especially in association with prematurity and infection.

Extraedge:

Enzyme deficiency states in order of prevalence: G6PD > pyruvate kinase > glucose-6- phosphate isomerase > rare deficiencies of other enzymes in the pathway.

questions.text: 45 year old patient presented with dyspnoea and history of angina. Blood is withdrawn and this blood shows a thick brownish colour. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methemoglobinemia Methemoglobinemia This is a diagnosis of exclusion because in sickle cell anemia, the history is presented with a paediatric history and there is paediatric consult.

Highyeild:

Comparison of carboxyhemoglobin, methemoglobin, and sulfhemoglobin Carboxyhemoglobin Methemoglobin Sulfhemoglobin Common causes ● Inhaled CO gas from fires, gas powered generators, kerosene heaters ● Smoking ● Ingested medication (dapsone, antimalarials) ● Local anesthetic ● Nitrates or nitrites ● Ingested medication (dapsone, phenacetin, sulfonamides) ● Nitrites Typical presentation + ● Neurologic symptoms from headache to coma ● Respiratory ● Cyanosis ● Neurologic symptoms from headache to coma ● Respiratory depression ● Cyanosis Color of the blood ● Cherry red ● Chocolate brown ● Green Pulse oximetry ● Inaccurate ● Inaccurate ● Inaccurate Arterial blood gas ● PaO 2 normal ● Carboxyhemoglobin is detected on most machines used in the United States ● PaO 2 normal ● Methemoglobin is detected on most machines used in the United States ● PaO₂ normal Confirmatory testing ● Co-oximetry using arterial blood (in stable patients, venous samples are accurate) ● Blood gas (arterial or venous) ● Requires specialized laboratory testing (spectrophotometry or gas chromatography) Management ● High-flow or hyperbaric oxygen ● Methylene blue (MB) or ascorbic acid ● Supportive (no antidote) ● Exchange transfusion in severe ● cases ● Lack of response to MB

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A sickle cell anemia There must be paediatric history given in the question in case of sickle cell anemia Option: B hemolytic anemia In hemolytic anemia there is no thick brownish red colour blood but there is pallor present Option: C -G6pd anemia In g6pd anemia there is intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria present with black urine

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heinz bodies Heinz bodies These are blood mixed with hypertonic solution of crystal violet the stain material is precipitates of denatured hemoglobin within cells Heinz bodies are also called as bite cells They are seen in hemolytic anaemia as informed in the question

questions.text: 42 year old patient was diagnosed with acute lung injury associated with transfusion. The mechanism behind this acute lung injury is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hla mediated The patient is diagnosed with acute lung injury associated with transfusion. This means that the patient is having TRALI - Transfusion related acute lung injury TRALI results from the transfusion of donor plasma containing high titres of anti Hla class 2 antibodies. This binds with the recipients leucocytes. This leukocytes gets aggregated in the pulmonary vasculature and they release the mediators that increase the capillary permeability. This is the main reason behind hla mediated acute lung injury following transfusion. Implicated donors are frequently multiparous women

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A Fluid overload This presents with dyspnoea with oxygen percentage greater than 90% on room air with bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray. Brain natriuretic peptide is often elevated and it is greater than 1.5 of pre-transfusion levels . Monitoring rate and volume of transfusion using diuretics will minimize the problem and does not lead to fluid overload Option: C Hypothermia Refrigerated (4 degree celsius) or frozen (-18 degrees celsius) blood can result in hypothermia when rapidly infused. Cardiac dysrhythmia can result from this. Option: D Plasma proteins Allergic reactions can be due to the plasma proteins found in the transfused components and acute lung injury cannot be caused by plasma proteins

Extraedge:

Diagnostic criteria for transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) and possible TRALI, as used since 200 TRALI Possible TRALI Acute lung injury (ALI)/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) ● Acute onset (during or within 6 hours of transfusion) ● Hypoxemia* ● Bilateral infiltrates on frontal chest radiograph ● No evidence of circulatory overload/left atrial hypertension ● No pre-existing ALI/ARDS before transfusion Same as for TRALI ALI/ARDS risk factor ¶ at time of transfusion Must be absent Must be present

questions.text: Patient , 23 years old, has undergone massive blood transfusion recently. All of the following can be the possible complications except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypokalemia Hypokalemia is not possible because there will be presence of hyperkalemia due to the RBC leaking during the storage. This will cause an increase in concentration of the potassium in the unit. . Preventive measures of this hyperkalemia includes using fresh or washed rbc because the complications can be fatal.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A Iron overload Iron overload is possible in blood transfusion because each unit of rbc contains 200 to 250 mg of iron . Option: B Hypocalcaemia Hypocalcemia is possible because the citrate is used as an anticoagulant in blood components. This citrate leads to the chelation of the calcium and inhibits the coagulation cascade leading to hypocalcemia Option: C Hyperkalemia Hyperkalemia is possible because t hat might be leakage of RBC during storage . This will cause an increase in the potassium concentration in the unit. Neonates and patients with renal failure are at risk. Preventive measures include using of fresh or washed rbc otherwise the complications can be fatal

Extraedge:

Massive transfusion was historically defined as transfusion of ≥10 units of whole blood (WB) or red blood cells (RBCs) in 24 hours. transfusion of 50% of the patient’s total blood volume over 3 h or >5–10 units of RBCC Reactions related to massive transfusion include citrate toxicity, hypothermia, hyperkalemia, and dilutional coagulopathy

questions.text: 60 year old female came with hemoglobin of 19 gram per deciliter. This happened on repeated occasions. Doctor wants to rule out polycythemia vera. What is the most reliable investigation to distinguish absolute and relative erythrocytosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Red cell mass Uniquely in polycythemia vera, in contrast to other causes of true erythrocytosis there is expansion of plasma volume, which can mask the elevated red cell mass. Particularly in women Thus red cell mass is necessary to establish the presence of erythrocytosis and thereby to rule out polycythemia vera Hence this is the most reliable investigation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A Hematocrit This is not done because there are a lot of diagnostic possibilities. However when a patient presents with erythrocytosis in combination with leukocytosis, thrombocytosis or splenomegaly or any combination of these, diagnosis is apparent Option: B Erythrocytosis This is not done because there is a lot of diagnostic possibilities. However when a patient presents with erythrocytosis in combination with leukocytosis, thrombocytosis or splenomegaly or any combination of these, diagnosis is apparent Option: D-Jak2 mutation assay assay for JAK 2 mutation in presence of normal arterial oxygen saturation provides an alternative diagnostic approach to erythrocytosis when red cell mass and plasma volume determinations are not available

Extraedge:

Causes of Erythrocytosis Relative Erythrocytosis Hemoconcentration secondary to dehydration, diuretics, ethanol abuse, androgens, or tobacco abuse Absolute Erythrocytosis Hypoxia Carbon monoxide intoxication High-oxygen-affinity hemoglobins High altitude Pulmonary disease Right-to-left cardiac or vascular shunts Sleep apnea syndrome Hepatopulmonary syndrome Renal Disease Renal artery stenosis Focal sclerosing or membranous glomerulonephritis Postrenal transplantation Renal cysts Bartter's syndrome Tumors Hypernephroma Hepatoma Cerebellar hemangioblastoma Uterine myoma Adrenal tumors Meningioma Pheochromocytoma Drugs Androgens Recombinant erythropoietin Famillal (with normal hemoglobin function) Erythropoietin receptor mutations VHL mutations (Chuvash polycythemia) 2,3-BPG mutation PHD2 and HIF2α mutations Polycythemia vera Abbreviations: 2,3-BPG, 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate; VHL, von Hippel-Lindau.

questions.text: Patient with the following peripheral smear also have dry marrow tap. All of the following are true except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coomb’s test always negative The presence of teardrop shaped red cells, nucleated red cells, myelocyte and promyelocytes along with dry tap establishes the diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis Intriguing feature of primary myelofibrosis is occurrence of autoimmune abnormalities such as immune complexes, antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor or a positive coomb's test Hence this option is false

questions.text: A 32 year male presents with anemia for evaluation. The blood picture shows microcytic anemia. The biochemical parameters shows: TIBC of 280 μg/dL; Serum iron of 40 μg/dL; Percentage saturation of 15%; Normal pattern on electrophoresis. What is the most probable cause of anemia in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anemia of inflammation The findings are suggestive of Anemia of inflammation . Option: A: TIBC > 360 μg/dL . Option: C: TIBC is Normal and abnormal hemoglobin (Beta) on electrophoresis. Option: D: Normal TIBC and Serum iron.

questions.text: A 32 year male while returning from regular health checkup on the way to his home met Road traffic accident leading to loss of about 500 ml of blood. Within a few min he arrives at ER and a blood investigation sample is sent. What is the most likely Hb of a patient when his earlier Hb was 12 g/dl?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

12 g/dl In any of these cases, after the sudden loss of a large amount of blood, there are three clinical/ pathophysiological stages . At first, the dominant feature is hypovolemia , which poses a threat particularly to organs that normally have a high blood supply, like the brain and the kidneys; therefore, loss of consciousness and acute renal failure are major threats . It is important to note that at this stage an ordinary blood count will not show anemia because the hemoglobin concentration is not affected. Option: B, C, D: Doesn’t decrease at early stage.

questions.text: A 5 year old male child presented with a history of passing reddish urine since 2 -3 days. Mother has noticed decreased urine output since this morning . She gives a history of a child having bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain 10 days ago . On examination pallor is seen . Blood investigations reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and raised LDH. Serum creatinine is 2.8mg/dl.Peripheral smear shows presence of schistocytes. Coagulation profile is normal. All the following are features of this condition EXCEPT
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neurological symptom This CHILD HAS PRESENTED 10 days after experiencing dysentery with classical triad of acute renal failure, microangiopathic haemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia suggestive of typical Hemolytic uremic syndrome(HUS) Fever and neurological features are not common in typical HUS and favour TTP as a diagnosis Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is characterized by:- Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia (MAHA): intravascular hemolysis + red cell fragmentation. ARF Thrombocytopenia Pathophysiology: - Endothelial damage triggers thrombosis, platelet consumption and fibrin deposition, mainly in the renal microvasculature. The strands cause mechanical destruction of passing red blood cells. Thrombocytopenia and ARF occur. Cause 90% due to E coli 0157 : produces a verotoxin which attacks endothelial cells. This affects young children most, often occurring in outbreaks due to consumption of undercooked contaminated meat, with abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea and ARF. Tests: Blood film: fragmented RBC platelets . (Clotting tests are normal comb;s test is negative). Treatment: No specific treatment –conservative management and antibiotics not necessary. Dialysis for ARF may be needed. Plasma exchange is used in cases of atypical HUS Eculizumab monoclonal antibody against C5 can be used in atypical HUS. Prognosis: Typical HUS has a good prognosis but Worse in non- E. Coli cases. Mortality 3-5%. Option A , B and D are included in HUS.

Extraedge:

Familial (Atypical) Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome (aHUS)- mostly affecting children, characterized by microangiopathic HA with presence of fragmented erythrocytes in the peripheral blood smear, thrombocytopenia (usually mild), and acute renal failure.

Solution:

Factor IX Cryoprecipitate Cryoprecipitate is a source of fibrinogen, factor VIII, and von Willebrand factor (vWF). It is ideal for supplying fibrinogen to the volume-sensitive patient. When factor VIII concentrates are not available, cryoprecipitate may be used since each unit contains approximately 80 units of factor VIII. Cryoprecipitate may also supply vWF to patients with dysfunctional (type II) or absent (type III) von Willebrand disease. Option A , C and D are a part of cryoprecipitate.

Extraedge:

Comparison of Fresh Frozen Plasma and Cryoprecipitate FFP Cryoprecipitate Volume 250 to 300 ml. 10 to 20 mL Time to prepare 30 minutes 30 minutes Fibrinogen 700 to 800 mg 150 to 250 mg Other coagulation factors All, including factors II, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI, and vWF Factors VIII, XIII, and vWF
